Lol no, this game is a fricking technical mess and even after a couple of patches its still a mess. The big publishers really are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ out utterly unoptimized games on PC lately and its totally shameful. I also love how this game is already going for less than the ~$42 I paid for it before launch.  I'll come back to this if they do fix it, but man they killed my interest in the game already and that's just a bummer for me.

I might as well have bought a Telltale Games title because being handed this mess after waiting literal years for it made me want to cry. Time to wait a few more weeks until the next update that's hopefully coming. Almost a month, a freaking month, and no definite fix. This broken games trend needs to stop. I'm not refunding because I still have some shred of hope for a fix. Let's hope two more weeks don't pass without some kind of update or Arkane will have sold me a 60 dollar Game-Crash simulator.   I'm beyond disheartened.  EDIT 12/5/2016, 3:42 PM: I installed it on my buddy's computer, a big beefy machine, and it has some stuttering issues and the mouse feels a tad wonky but it's a good game. I just cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone that doesn't have a top-of-the-line machine or a console.   Wait it out. Read the reviews. This one will be edited when the definitive fix comes out.

12/2/16 Patch 1.3 Update :  The game runs better than it did after a few patches but it still features unacceptably poor performance. So as of now, I'd still advise people to stay away from it.  I've since been able to add some stability by turning off SLI and switching to windowed mode at a lower resolution with V-Sync on. This seems to have alleviated a lot of crashing issues so far, and performance hovers between 40-50 fps. It's at least playable this way, but I'm still experiencing the odd crash and performance still randomly tanks in the sub-20 fps range for no discernible reason, resulting in gameplay gaffes and general frustration.  I'll fully revise this review once I finish the game and a few more patches have rolled out. But as of right now, it's a still a thumb's down due to its horrible performance. What a huge disappointment.   Original Review :  Stay far, far away from this one unless you like wasting money.   After just a couple of hours I've been absolutely plagued by freezes and crashes. Not sure what's causing it, but they're pretty frustrating. They occur randomly in-game, but the game also has a bad tendency to crash out of even a menu.  Additionally the game runs really poorly on my hardware to begin with. I'm running an i7-4790 with 780ti SLI on an SSD, all my drivers are updated, and it still runs terribly on even the lowest settings. It's not even so much that I see a low framerate -- Even though I certainly do, I'm averaging about 35 fps overall on medium settings -- It's that the framerate fluctuates wildly for seemingly no reason. For example, I'll play through a certain area and see around 45 fps, then quick reload because I screwed something up, and play through the same exact area averaging 28 fps. It makes no sense. And toggling graphics settings seems to help nothing: I get maybe a 5 fps variance between the lowest settings and putting everything to high. Something is severely wrong with this game, and seeing how broken it is removes almost all of my hope that it'll ever be fixed. From what I understand it even runs poorly on consoles: I've seen many complaints about crashes on the PS4. So maybe this is a Void Engine thing, I dunno. But I sure wish they had just built Dishonored 2 on the Unreal Engine, like Dishonored 1 was.  This is the worst running PC game I've played since Assassin's Creed Unity's release back in 2014. I'll update my review should this game ever stabilize, though even that is no guarantee. Once a game releases in this bad of shape it's rare to ever see it run well.  Now we know why Bethesda didn't want to ship review copies to journalists covering the game. Because it barely works. Shame on you Bethesda for such shady business practices, and shame on you for releasing a game with so much potential in such a sorry state.
Unless your PC is comparable in power to a nuclear submarine, expect combat to play out like a powerpoint presentation.

So a couple of days ago I got this game with the current discount that Steam offers (33% off) I thought frankly the game wasn't only incredibly badly optimized, but also it was a boring and dull experience, I didn't experience crashes or anything of the sort, but I did experience framedrops on the second mission during the infamous intro sequence as well as when staring down towards the city from the balcony.  I tried every setting imaginable and I just couldn't get a playable framerate, I tried everything I could, but for my standars, (which are high because I guess i'm a jerk) the game was just unplayable, it drop to the low 40 fps with some settings set to the lowest that they could get, in other cases the game just simply refused to stay above 30 fps, and so on and so forth, after having a confusing, and frustrating experience, I pretty much just refunded the game, that was of course until today.  I found a deal for the game at a 'legit' website (according to a Bethesda representative that hangs around some forums on reddit) and whooptie doo, here we have my review. And I managed to fix my performance issues, How?  Welp...  i5 6600k gtx 970 24 gb of ram  Those up there are my system specs, not to shabby, not to incredible, in my honest opinion, just a decent enough build.  I first disabled vsync completely, it turns out the input lag as well as the fact that it's the type of vsync that imposes double buffering, an uncommon form of applying vsync now a days, usually games use triple buffering without even telling you, to my understanding the simple rule of this to forms of vsync goes like this, double buffered locks your framerate at the half of your monitor's refresh rate, so if my monitor has an hz of 60, the game will simply lock my framerate to 30.  Triple buffering fixes this, but sadly it introduces an absurd amount of input lag, so the only solution for this was to disable vsync completely, something that both fixed in it's entirety the issue with the input lag, as well as the framerate issue, for the most part.  The second thing that I did was to set the game at the 'default settings' meaning to have the game running at the recommended settings that the game offers based on my system specs.  It appears it set everything to the 'medium' preset, the game looks good, nothing spectacular, nothing ugly, just good.  And... That's pretty much it, the game now runs and plays just fine, I just finished the first two levels and I felt the need to give a write up for this, maybe I experience problems at a later date, I hope not, but there.  DIshonored 2 as a game, when talking about the core, of the story, of the gameplay, of the actual experience, it's an absolute masterpiece so far, and i've put in maybe around two hours or so, with the first one being the one that made me slap my head and refund the game, and with the second one being one fueled by my curiosity as well as by my care for my limited income.  And i'm glad in all honesty that I purchased the game again, I really enjoy it, but that's not to say the game doesn't have it's fare share of problems, the game is plaguated by performance issues across all systems, for what i'm reading.  Maybe I could recommend it for people that don't mind dropping the settings down a bit, nor do other people that maybe don't mind playing the game at 30fps just like the rest of the platforms do, overall tho, I really hope they fix this on pc, because what i'm experiencing now, after a lot of trial an error, and just a lot of pacience and tolerance, is not what the regular buyer needs nor will it do, in most cases people will simply forget about the game and move along, and for a game that was clearly made with this much passion, with as much attention to detail, and with as much care, I frankly don't think it's fair, not to the consumer, and not to the creators themselves, to have them releasing this much of a broken mess.  Even then, i'm recommending it, because in my experience, is a great game, incredible really... If you can get it to play.

Without a high end pc, don't buy this game yet. Last year's mainstream king and #1 most popular card on Steam, the $350 gtx 970, is  below recommended specs . CPU needs 4 cores @4+ GHz (Intel Haswell 4th gen), but I wouldn't try it on my old AMD fx 8300 8-core @4.6 (below spec). Even with patches and gfx updates it's possible that mid-range systems won't comfortably run, so please wait for more news  My performance issues are minimal at 1440p with a 1070 and 6600k @4.6 GHz, but I preemptively lowered settings like shadows, fog, and AO. Frames are 60+ but frequently jump. I may try triple buffered Vsync with 60fps limit. Mouse issues are another story. Mouse sensitivity/acceleration is very inconsitent, even with smoothing and friction off. It's uncomfortable and needs a fix asap  Gameplay is fun with some complaints, but I'm giving this negative due to Bethesda's anti-consumer practices like not giving review copies, and the numerous issues at launch. If it's patched to allow mid-range systems to play, and some elements are fixed like the spam slide-kill, then I'll change to positive

I go into the settings, set everything to ultra low, I'm now looking at a 'stellar' 50-60fps (barely). My performance should be through the roof on ultra low and yet it's as if I've only gone from ultra to high or very high.   Sensitivity and leaning are weirdly implemented and do not feel right. They'll vary from situation to situation without much reason.  I really loved D1 and I want to play this so bad but I cannot fathom playing the rest of the game at sub 60fps on a perfectly capable rig. I look to Arkane to fix these issues once the game officially launches for everyone. I have never reviewed a game before, but I had to get this out there.   The PC port of Dishonored 2 is a huge disappointment. The first Dishonored had a pretty great port, and I was extremely excited to play Dishonored 2. The game itself feels like it would be a great successor to the first, if it actually ran the way it should. The game looks great, but not great enough to warrant the terrible performance issues. Most of the six hours I've 'played' has been me tinkering with settings to try to get a solid 60 FPS, but I just can't seem to get above about 48 FPS on any settings at all. It really is a shame that the game launched so poorly optimized. They just released an official patch, which seems to have increased framerates in areas that didn't have trouble in the first place, but if there are open areas with a lot going on, the game still has issues keeping up. The patch they've released two weeks after launch now still isn't enough to make the game play like it should.   In closing, save your money. Even if you're a diehard fan, wait until they actually fix the game or wait until a big sale on the title. It really is a shame that we are still getting terrible ports of AAA games, when developers know that a large PC market is there. I really wanted this game to be great, but I just can't recommend it at this time.

I have just completed two playthroughs, one with Corvo the other with Emily. It was a great journey, but also a VERY short one. The game took me about 10 hours to complete, on both playthroughs. For a RPG in 2016, 10 hours is in my opinion an outragously short duration. My playthroughs were done leisurely as well, collecting all runes and bonecharms, doing all side quests, and reading through the plethora of notes and books in game. I can only imagine how much shorter it would be if NOT taking your time.  The game has some serious technical issues, terrible optimization and a lot of graphical glitches. I can play any other new games like BF1 on medium settings 1080p res and get 45FPS on average. This game I cant even maintain 20 FPS on low/medium settings at lower resolutions. The game also has really wierd visuals, objects and things get jaggedy and the AA goes crazy when they are further than about 15 feet away. The edges get jagged and blurry and it just looks like crap, but those same objects look great when your up close to them. I dont know if thats from the game itself or a product of my visual settings, but I hate it.  The gameplay is GREAT and its so much fun which is why its such a shame that the game suffers from so many issues and a dreadfully short play time. The powers are a blast and sword fighting is exhilarating. Both Emily and Corvo have their own unique magic and skills and it lets you play your own way, stealthy or assault style. The plot is decent although feels like its taking a few too many pages from the original game. The typical political coupe or overthrow and the missions are the same, basically kill this person.   The first dishonored was good but I felt like the Devs couldnt find another gameplay loop, they couldnt build the missions around anything but kill this person. And every mission your out to kill someone else responsible. Theres maybe one or two where your doing something different but the basic layout is hunting the people responsible. Kind of shallow, but overall it works for the most part.   I feel very dissapointed. Maybe ive been spoiled by all the great games recently, but personally I think 10 hours for an RPG is unacceptable. Its just too short. Ill get maybe 30 hours of gameplay out of this game before Im completely over and burned out of it. The Witchers DLC Blood and Wine provided me with TWICE the play time, and that was just DLC. I hate to compare games like that but my point is in this day and age, the way games are, this is just short, plain and simple.  WAIT FOR A SALE, this was not worth $60 in my opinion, not even the preorder bonus of getting the first dishonored, not just because I already had it but because even the two games together in my opinion are not worth $60.  I was so excited to play this, counting minutes on store page on release day, and now a mere 48 hours later I cant even play it anymore, Ive done 3 playthroughs now, and its just not fun anymore because Ive done everything so many times. This game is depressingly short, makes me sad :(. I dont get how it took them so long to develop and make this when its such a small game.

Whenever I buy games on launch day, I always seem to get screwed. I pulled the trigger on Arkham Knight, and pulled the trigger on this one.  This game in it's current form is unplayable. It is sooo badly optimized.  I spent an hour of my 1.4 hours in this game fiddling with the visuals and mouse settings thinking it was my setup, but it isn't. The frames drop harder than Skrillex bass. Everything is great whe you're standing still but as soon as you move the mouse to look left or right, frames instantly drop to about 15 fps in my situation. Also, the mouse does this weird thing where at the start of movement, it moves really slow, as if in syrup, then immediately zooms right the hell away lightning fast meaning good luck trying to aim accurately at anything ever. Arkham Knight was terrible but it was blatantly obvious with the frame drop. This does it in a way that is almost inperceptable. Like I said, it seemed like it was something that could be fixed by lowering a few settings, which is why it took me so long to realize it was the game, It literally made my head hurt. When I finally threw in the towel and lowered everything to the lowest setings possible and still had Skrillex level drops, I headed straight here to see reviews. I will wait a few days to see if this is patched, before deciding on wether i need to return it or not. I was seriously looking forward to this and the game mechanics and story themselves look like they'll be great, but I need to be able to play this without getting a huge migraine.  DO NOT BUY unless this is patched.  For reference,  Windows 10 64-bit 24GB Ram GTX 980Ti Overclocked GTX 960 overclocked Intel i5 4690k CPU  running the game at 2560x1080p

I remember when Bethesda announced Dishonored 2 at E3 2015, and how excited I was. I loved the first dishonored a lot, especially the Daud DLCs. I got even more hyped with the gameplay shown at Bethesda’s E3 2016 conference. I let myself get so hyped for the game that I even bought the collector’s edition (Its funny how the last three games I got the collectors editions for were dissapointing.) And so when the game arrived at my doorstep I loaded it and got to playing… and was greeted by a myriad of technical issues. I find it strange that Arkane of all companies would release a shoddy PC port, considering their first game was exclusive to pc and their second ran perfectly. Of course I was so determined to still enjoy the game that I continued on, 15-20 FPS be damned. After forcing myself through the game by sheer stubbornness, I left disappointed, not just by the buggy state of the game but also by the lackluster writing, pacing, and poor delivery from the vocal talent. Yes, some of the voice actors do an alright job, but the others leave a lot to be desired. Its also baffling how quickly everyone jumps ship to Delilah’s side at the beginning. You’d think that after the first Dishonored everyone wouldn’t be too quick to decide that Corvo was behind the murders after having been framed before, but oh well then purpose of the plot what not.. And the pacing is just terrible. In the first dishonored it took a bit before everything went to hell, yet in Dishonored 2 all that happens before you’re kicked from power is a cutscene (which you can skip by the way,) excluding the optional tutorial. The dialogue feels a little stilted and awkwardly spoken in brief phrases, and most of the nonlethal eliminations feel wimpy and underwhelming.    Hell, you non lethaly eliminate Delilah more or less the same way you did in the Daud DLC’s, and just trap her in another one of her paintings    None of them (save one, Jindosh) feel like a cruel mercy, where killing the target is far nicer than the alternative. Most of the levels are forgettable. The first and last level in the game are the same map, just different in appearance. The only two levels that feel memorable are the Clockwork Mansion and a Crack in the Slab. Gameplay wise Corvo’s powers feel superior to Emily, at least when it comes to stealth. Aside from that the gameplay is still as smooth as ever, so that’s a plus. Ultimately I left feeling disappointed. If you liked the game, cool, more power to you. As for me, it just didn’t connect. 5/10, I suppose. EDIT: Also it uses DRM.

The performance of the game is surprisingly lack luster. I had an R9 280 and I pretty much had to run this on low everything to get a decent frame rate. I ended up deciding to do that overdue upgrade and picked up a GTX 1060 6gb and there were times when this game STILL ran as low as 10 fps in complex environments, though with settings maxed out completely. For the most part it cruised along at about 30 fps. Meanwhile, COD Advanced Warfare was well over 60 fps, consistently, Mirror's Edge Catalyst is well over 60 FPS, consistently... Clearly bethesda and arkane did not do even a decent job of optimizing this for the PC market. and that sort of sheer negligence speaks about the companies which throttle a game's success. However, being a big fan of the first game, I decided to be a big boy and get over it. Once you can get past the performance problems (if you are capable) then the game itself is quite good.   The overall story isn't bad, it's fine. Once you clear the intro to the game, you can pretty much figure out the final outcome. There are some great concepts they flesh out during the game, and a few points where they give the player a surprising amount of control over the immediate plot if the player thinks ever so slightly out of the box and off the game's 'rails' (the dust district mission, and the stilton house... that's all I'm going to say).   The amount of thought put into the different elements of the environment is impressive. The amount of detail in every aspect of the game is great, and there's huge amounts of lore to track down and enjoy. The clockwork mansion had elements that were surprisingly well thought out for an FPS as well.  The gameplay was great. If you're a stealth game nut like me, you're going to love this. Arkane did a great job of making you feel like an assassin lurking along rooftops, rafters while stalking your target and avoiding detection. If you're not a stealth nut, then the combat is still pretty fun. I played through the game twice, once good and once evil, and both paths are equally fun. The exploration potential in the game is huge as well. I got bored with exploring considering how much time I spent at it, and upon my second play through I still found areas I handn't seen yet.  Sound and music were well done, no complaints there.  The endings were a bit short and felt a little lack luster. Like, you could more or less predict what was going to happen once you had made decisions, and even then I was surprised that some of the decisions I had made had no bearing whatsoever on the ending. It felt like this was another area where things felt like they didn't get enough attention, but it could also be that the creators didn't want to broaden the potential endings so dramatically that a third potential game would have to ignore many of the outcomes and stick to a very specific cannon outcome. Whatever the case, I was actually a bit disappointed in the endings I was able to explore.  Overall, I do recomend this game, though I strongly caution players to research their GPU's ability with the game, and do NOT expect the same performance you get from other games with similar visuals. The R9 280 chugged pretty hard on this one, and ultimately this was the catalyst to go for a significant upgrade, and even then the game had moments of surprisingly low performance. Do your homework, check your gpu to see what it can do especially in the complex environments and decide what you're willing to accept. If you can do that and you find yourself at peace with your expectations, then get this game because it's really well made.

Quick point: Wait for sale, gauge your interest in this style of a game.   Review: Dishonored 2 in my opinion is the closest thing we'll ever get to a Thief 4. While most people will shout negatives at this game on steam for performance. The only negative I have with the game is that it's not 'Thief' enough. The sound design is not as good as the Thief series and that is integral to a First Person Stealth Sim like Dishonored wants to be. The fact that sound does not matter until 'Very Hard' and even then it's not really a true mechanic is quite puzzeling to me. The only other negative I have is that I cannot retract Corvo's blade and use it as an equivalent to the Black Jack from Thief. I am fine with choking people out but the fact that it's almost my only option to knock people out is kinda lame IMO.   Before I move forward with my review I would like to say that if they make a Dishonored 3 PLEASE give us that choice. I think it would be cool to be in situations where some guards have metal helmets, so that, I have no other choice BUT to choke them out. Then a lot of guards would be wearing hats or nothing at all and I could just run up to them and bop them on the head. It would be so much more interesting to me from a gameplay perspective.Then If they also made sound matter imagine having to worry about being on Marble, Stone, Metal, and anything that makes a lot of noise. Those are the gameplay elements of Thief that I loved to death. Jumping down from above onto my Moss Arrow patch and then smacking a guard on the head. It was seamless gameplay, no context sensitive BS.   Anyways, sorry for that loooong tangent but it had to be said. Overall I DO LOVE this game a lot. It and DOOM are my favorite games of the entire year. The performance issues on my end have been completely ironed out. Plus, I bought it on sale so not having to pay that full sixty was definitely a plus. The game definitely captures MOST of Thief's style. It's like 80% there. Stephen Russell voicing Corvo alone is literally enough to bump that up to 85% if I'm being totally honest. Just like Thief and Garrett of the past Corvo will comment on things around him and make witty quips. The dialogue is pretty damn good so far and I would say it's pretty on par with Thief. This game was my dream come true in a nutshell. I totally say give it a shot if you loved Thief.

Unlike many others, I have not had a problem running Dishonored 2, so I can't comment on the issues that some have seen. What I can say is that if you were a fan of the original game, Dishonored 2 improves on nearly every aspect of Dishonored. The option for high and low chaos is still there and both can be played either in a more action or stealth mode but added to this is the choice to play as either Corvo or Emily. This is not merely a choice of skins as Emily's powers are different from Corvo's. Corvo's is consistent with the first game but Emily offers new powers like Link (what happens to one linked enemy happens to the other(s)); Doppelganger (creating a duplicate of yourself for distraction or fighting purposes); and Shadow Walk (taking on a stealthy shadow form to move about more discreetly). Also, the game adds the ability to break down normal bone charms to create custom charms with multiple traits. Dark and corrupted bone charms can be sacrificed for material but the traits which they held will be lost.  The best feature of the game though is the level design. Dishonored had some great levels, but Dishonored 2 has levels equal to the first and two levels that are among the best in gaming. If you are someone who does not explore levels but simply follows the waypoints to complete objectives there is a lot that will be missed. I'm sure that type of player will find some enjoyment in the game but where the game shines is in exploring the hidden away spots and seeing all the detail that was included in the level design.   Story-wise the game draws a lot from the two story expansions of Dishonored (The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches). You don't need to have played these to understand what happens in Dishonored 2 but those who have played the expansions will have more background on a couple of major players. The story also expands the world of Dishonored as most of the time is spent in Karnaca instead of Dunwall. As in the first your actions will affect some areas of the game, with high chaos leading to more blood fly (the equivalent of rats from the first game; though rats are present here as well) infested areas.   Three games really shine for me this year: Doom, Deus Ex: Mankind Divided, and Dishonored 2. The first two seem like worthy titles in their respective franchises. Doom returned to the feel of the first two games and added some elements that made it a lot of fun to play. Mankind Divided was a great sequel that was the equal of Human Revolution. But Dishonored 2 took the step up to the next level for that franchise for me. For that reason, it's my favorite game of 2016.

It's unfortunate that this game has been rated so poorly on Steam purely on the basis of a choppy start. I certainly understand peoples frustration, however having waited a few weeks for the patches I've now put in a fair bit of time and I can confidently say this game is exceptionally good - even better than the first title in my opinion.  The ingenuity behind the level design is astonishing. I haven't encountered a game offering so many routes to objectives with such intricacy. Exploration is very rewarding - although the storyline is linear, the scale and detail of the maps makes the game at times feel like a sandbox title. The graphics, although arguably technically not the best to date, are absolutely beautiful, with particular attention paid to clever lighting, shading and use of colours. If you enjoyed the first game or you enjoy challenging stealth titles, Dishonored 2 is a must buy.  The performance issues appear to have been resolved with one exception. I would strongly recommend to Nvidia users disabling HBAO+ in advanced options - as with a lot of other titles (GTA V, Far Cry 4 etc.) it really does kill the frame rate. With the GTX 1070 I can play the game at 2560x1440 at a mix of Ultra/Very High, TXAA and adaptive resolution disabled and the performance is flawless. HBA0+ was enabled by default however and I found the game very choppy before disabling it. The graphical difference without it is marginal, you won't miss it.  Edit: Having now completed the game I can reiterate that it was truly excellent, definitely game of the year for me. I have had no performance issues whatsoever since disabling HBAO+. After completing it I immediately decided to replay it on hard with a different playstile - with a huge backlog of games I've yet to play I can think of no higher praise than this.

Tl;dr: same story as everyone else. Optimization was and to an extent is (for some) still terrible. Release state was abysmal. Wait for more patches and a sale.  My rig: i5 4690k OC 4.4GHz GTX970 SSC 16GB ram (8x8 in single channel due to faulty mob) Runs Titanfall 2 and BF1 maxed out smoothly despite single channel ram so take what you will from that.   As of patch 1.3 (almost one month since release) there are still some weird graphical issues going on but it seems mostly smoothed out if you fiddle with the settings enough. I managed to get stable framerates at 1080p by locking the FPS to 45 and turning most things up to very high. That being said, the game shouldn't have been released on PC as it was. A delay would have been preferable. Arkane and Bethesda messed up.  As most reviewers have said, I'd probably give the game a thumbs up if not for the state of the optimization. It's got a well built world to play around in and the NPC's are less rigid than most other games. They seem to be a living part of the world rather than just set pieces. The dialogue can be a bit cringe at points, but it's rare enough to be forgivable. I had a few frustrations with the control scheme at first but it's definitely workable. Overall it's an enjoyable experience if you're a fan of the stealth genre or the world of Dishonored.  As for the graphics, it's a pretty game. It really is. Is it the prettiest game of 2016? No. Battlefield 1 is by far better looking and Titanfall 2 (made in heavily modified Source, btw) is as well imo. Opinions over art style will differ, but in plain graphical fidelity it's pretty handily beaten by other holiday releases. The issues people have had since release are not because this is a new AAA game with the fanciest graphics to date that require a beasty GPU with 6-8gb of vram to run, it's because Arkane chose to cannibalize the ID Tech engine and turn it into the Void engine. I assume because it was at hand and saved on licensing fees. Wrong move on their part.  If you really wanna give the game a shot I HIGHLY recommend waiting for a sale or picking it up on console. Definitely don't give Bethesda/Arkane your $60 for this either way. They knew the state of the game when they released it and took advantage of Bethesda's new day 1 review policy to push it out the door anyway. I regret buying at release and being too stubborn to return it while I had the chance. By this time next year it'll hit less than half price in Steam sales and (hopefully) be properly optimized. This will definitely be my last day 1 purchase from Bethesda for a long time to come.

User's are suggesting fixes such as setting gpu to use Prefer maximum power, pre-rendered frames to 1 and turning VSync on. For me this doesn't help. It plays just like the first game but does it better. The levels are longer, more lively, and D2 still keeps the basics of gameplay from D1 while adding a bit of new perks to the powers to keep it fresh. Aside from the frame issues which will be eventually patched, Dishonored 2 blows every game I've ever played out of the water (and I've played just about everything). There is so much detail put into the game world; you can see how weathered the walls are with their scratches and marks, there's tiny notches on the wood doors, scratches and marks of your metallic sword (with realtime reflections), the scars on the NPCS, the ebb and flow motion of the water, and the gorgeous color scheme of skyline and shadows that reflects the time of day, etc. It looks freaking amazing. The game doesn't try to be photorealistic and improves on the art style from the first game. The dialogue from distinguished voice acting cast and animations are superb, the gameplay is open ended, and there's so much to explore that I know I won't be able to see it all in one playthrough. Its story and gameplay is done really well, a rarity as most games will do one portion effectively yet neglect the other.   If you're a fan of the Bioshock series, Thief series (excluding the 4th one), the first Dishonored, Deus Ex, or just love atmospheric games that focus on lore then this game is for you. This was my favourite game in 2016. As a preface, I had none of the performance issues experienced by many people, so I cannot comment on that, purely on the game itself when it's running fine. I understand that some people are having trouble even with hardware that should be fine, but on my end I had smooth >60 fps the entire game. Whether I'm just lucky or not I'm not sure, but it worked great for me.  Dishonored 2 really expanded on the story of the first game, and kept the really weird techno-fantasy setting on the first game going strong. The levels are full of intricate things that are so alien yet so consistent that it feels like a believable world, and the Stranger and the Void are always interesting every time it pops up.  As for the gameplay itself, I really liked the way it always felt like I had options. I chose Corvo at the beginning, and mostly played through stealthily, the only kills I got were a couple of unintentional ones where I accidentally left an unconsious guard in a puddle of water, and when an enemy got knocked off the side of a building by my sleep dart. None of the missions pigeonholed me into making a choice I didn't want. Even one mission that at first seemed to require the death of a faction leader eventually opened up to reveal a third option as I looked around the area.  The levels themselves are all great in this regard, always unique from each other and each having all sorts of different ways to get through them depending on what powers and such you're using. Especially noteworthy is the clockwork mansion, which I won't spoil but when it all first starts moving aorund it's just really intersting to get into. At no point during anything did it feel like a chore, and I honestly can't think of any spots in the game I didn't like.  Looking forward to replaying it with Emily and perhaps doing a full-agression run. Highly reccomend provided it runs okay on your computer.

At present, I just  cannot  recommend getting this game. I wish I could, it has so many great elements and a lot of promise, but they are easily overshadowed by a large amount of truly baffling technical issues.  But to start off with the good things:    You get to play as two characters this time around, and you get to pick. They differ in details like their powers, but this difference leads to rather large changes in how you traverse levels and handle combat or stealth.    Stealth is more satisfying this time around, seemingly buildings and spaces have been set up with greater care to provide more of a puzzle. I play on hard, and I've been killed a fair few times for not planning things out well enough.    Story seems interesting so far, always a plus.    New settings compared to the first game. I mean in the end the world is just as screwed up there as in Dunwall, but the change of scenery is quite cool.   Now to the bad parts, and as I said, they easily eclipse the above. This is based on the 1.2 beta patch, performance is much worse without it:  For one, the optimization is  terrible , and that's putting it very very mildly. The game runs alright on hardware which should make it soar. And even then constantly stutters or drops frames in seemingly random situations.  Next up, someone implemented  negative mouse acceleration . This really only makes sense if someone is playing with a touchpad, even with a controller it feels mushy and weird. They ought to just remove it entirely instead of trying to tweak it like they did in the patch. Or at least explain why they'd even have this, it serves no purpose in a FPS.  Third, the options are just broken. Toggling bloom also toggles screen dirt and lens dirt effects? Setting textures too high results in them loading at lowest detail? Lots of settings having absolutely no effect on framerate? Most not even on visibly quality? All there. Also ofc the staples of 'modern' interactive movies, forced film grain effect (cannot turn it off), ridiculously overdone motion blur, depth of field despite already blurring everything with FXAA or TXAA, bloom so strong it feels like your monitor is acting up. At least other than the film grain, you can turn these off. Still, this is a video game, you'd think the effects were optimized for it, not for a movie.  Fourth, because this really bears stating again: The game looks like something from 2014, and runs like something from 2030. There's no excuse for this, and I just cannot recommend getting it. At all.

I caught the game on a Steam sale and decided to jump in, regardless of all the bug reports. I can only report on my experiences:  1) The gameplay is outstanding. Take Dishonored 1, improve your non-lethal combat *extensively* and you have Dishonored 2. Now you don't have to sacrifice having a good time because lots of the 'fun' gameplay is lethal -- non-lethal is viable and just as fun.  Right now I'm on my first playthrough with Emily and her powers are interesting. Cool stuff. I'm looking forward to trying Corvo's different powers (haven't even seen them yet).  2) Graphics -- They are really good. More actual detail than the first Dishonored and even more 'dense' - It can take hours to explore a particular area because there are so many nooks and crannies.  3) Sound -- The sound is very good, with environmental sounds and great (non-intrusive) music to back it all up. The voice acting for many of the characters, though, is absolutely comical, in a bad way. They really need to look into hiring some better voice actors for the normal enemies - heck, I'll offer my services for free.  4) Game performance - So I use a 960GTX on a Xeon (i7) 3.5Ghz and performance is acceptible if I turn off V-sync. V-sync does some weirdness -- slows down the mouse response, everything feels like it's 1/10th second 'behind' my input. Of course, I have to live with the tearing, but overall it's much better to have some tearing and great responsiveness.  Frame-rates go from 70-30. Usually, even in the 30FPS areas (dense with lots of objects and enemies) it still feels pretty good in actual gameplay, but there are some quirks (mentioned later in bugs).  5) Bugs -- Unfortunately, the game is fairly buggy, but so far (thankfully) not game-breakingly so.  For instance -- you can craft bonecharms or runes, which is awesome -- and you can even stack effects on bonecharms to have them stack.  Except the beneficial traits (like choking someone out or moving with a body) are DETRIMENTAL -- Arkane made the ridiculous mistake of flipping their logic, so that equipping a 'Choke someone faster' charm (or 4) will slow your choke speed....how disappointing.  As for graphics - mostly stable, but sometimes I run into craziness -- I'm playing on Hard, so about 2 hits from a sword kills me (which I like) but when I bring up the powers menu to try to select a power, sometiems I'm 'stuck' in that I can't select a power----I have to press escape to try to exit the game, then try to enter the menu again. Really annoying and has led to several deaths.  Overall -- An awesome game if technical issues don't plague you -- I run on decently high settings and love the graphics -- can't wait to upgrade my GPU and play on higher settings eventually.  The level design is absolutely awesome -- Clockwork Mansion being something I've never seen in a game and the design is almost mind-boggling.   I really hope they fix lots of the bugs though -- some of them are so easy to spot and yet they made it into the game.

Dishonored 2 is exactly the sequel I wanted. Unlike many other newer games, it feels like the developers were left alone to just make the game they wanted, as there are no microtransactions, no multiplayer, and no cliffhanger ending with delusional aspirations to make this a huge franchise. This is just as tight and focused as the first game. The few problems are either technical, or the same things the last game did wrong.  The biggest improvement in Dishonored 2 over its predecessor is how the developers have learned to marry player movement with the level design. This is something they improved on with the DLC for the original, and here they’ve refined it further. It’s what makes the level design stand out compared to other games of this type, as they haven’t used your athletic abilities as an excuse to turn it into an open world game. Instead it has the small scale focus of Thief, Deus Ex or Hitman, with a movement system that makes it feel like you can go wherever you want. Obviously, with double jumping and teleporting, there needs to be barriers. But the developers have done a remarkably good job of designing natural barriers around the levels that don’t break the illusion of it being a believable world. This isn’t like Battlefield with its “leaving the combat area” notifications, which are probably the worst way to do it.  There are two playable protagonists this time, which is something that works nicely with the kind of game this is. The game allows a refreshing amount of unpredictable chaos to happen in the levels. When you start a mission, guards and NPCs all wander around on predictable routes. But interesting things start happening when you poke at their routines. The game allows guards to follow you across the entire level, and if they lose sight of you, they don’t immediately return to their old positions. This opens up possibilities for all sorts of guerilla tactics, as you can lead them on a wild goose chase to the other side of the map, and then return to previously guarded areas and loot them while they’re still busy searching for you elsewhere. I haven't played something this willing to let complete anarchy spread inside its levels since Saint's Row 2. It's a kind of game design I wish we'd see more of. So even though you play through the same missions with both characters, this is a game where replaying doesn’t feel like a waste of time.  Even though levels are segmented into separate zones, they don’t “feel” like game arenas. For example in Thief 4 and the last two Deus Ex games, levels were subdivided into smaller arena sized areas for streaming, which is something Dishonored 2 doesn't do. Instead the game has pretty brutal RAM requirements, with the benefit of more interesting design. There’s such a density of optional content and alternative routes that the environments gain a sense of naturalness most games don’t achieve. The art direction also manages to meld characters and interactable objects to a cohesive whole, to the extent where it can be hard to see where enemies are, and what you’re able to pick up. In a slow paced game like this, that's a positive, as it encourages you to stay on alert at all times, as you’ll otherwise miss how a room can be swarming with traps and enemies. It also makes the game look more like concept art come to life, as the graphics aren’t overloaded with thick outlines and spotlights telling you what you’re supposed to look out for. This isn’t the most technically advanced game to come out this year, but it’s easily the best looking, as the artists used the tech to its fullest. The balance of colors and dynamic range is near perfect, creating a style that will age marvelously.  The chaos system returns, changing the ending of the game based on how many people you kill. I didn't like how the system worked in the first game, but here I found it alright. The two playable characters have personalities that fit one or the other approaches better. Emily is being slandered by political opponents, who accuse her of assassinating her rivals. Playing her as a killer feels like you'd be playing into the hands of her critics. But if you play as Corvo, you're basically Liam Neeson, making it perfectly in character just to murder everybody. Playing as Emily, I bent over backwards finding solutions to knock out enemies instead of killing them. For example, if I was discovered, I jumped up on shelves or lamps to do leaping knockdown attacks, often managing to take out entire groups of enemies. And even if a few people died, either by accident or by me running out of patience, the system isn't particularly harsh. You have to kill more than 10 people per level before you're classified as high chaos.  As for the story, it's a mixed bag. The voice direction in key emotional scenes is poor, and the characterization is generally flat. Take Emily Caldwell. Even toward the end I had no idea how she had been managing as an empress, or even a basic outline of her personality. Everything pointed toward her being totally incompetent, and I’m not sure if that was the intent? In cutscenes she talks about things she’s learning, and how the journey has changed her, but it feels unnatural and forced. This story isn’t nearly as good as Thief 1-3, but it thankfully isn't a trainwreck like Thief 4. The story here does the job alright, about on par with the last game, but it isn’t memorable in the least. Almost all dialog felt more like filler than a real story.  It’s too bad the story is so-so, as it doesn't feel like it went anywhere interesting with its characters. It puts more of a damper on my feelings about Dishonored 2 than the game deserves. But you can’t underestimate how big of an emphasis we put on how something ends, without it being something we have conscious control over. Still, I can only see it as a huge positive that I’m genuinely considering playing it a second time. It's one of the best designed games I've played this year, and I like it more than the first one.

Pros:  - Huge open ended levels with multiple points of entry to nearly every building - Fantastic voice acting - Very immersive, makes you really feel like you're apart of the world through readables and witty quips - Choices you make do leave an impact in the game - Enemy AI is really good - Mini city hubs before each main mission are a blast to go through, the ingame shops are a very nice touch too - Very beautiful artwork and stunning visuals - Clockwork soldiers are freakin' awesome from the voice work to the design of them. Very cool. - The ability to play lethally or non-lethally and offering up very creative ways to get rid of a target.  Cons  - Performance issues, I have a high end rig but even ran into the occasional lagging points myself. I imagine on even a moderately built PC there to be performance issues too - The story, I am keeping this spoiler free but lets just say the chances are quite high that you will enjoy the little stories told as you go along rather than the main over arching story. - Bugs bugs bugs! If you're trying to go for a shadow achievement or a no kill achievement be careful where you rest bodies and be sure to regulary check the menu that the game hasn't accidentally ticked you off for something you weren't aware of. Very frustrating - The game really tends to teach you that killing is bad, I feel that it really caters towards the non-lethal stealth approach but of course you can be a killer too.  Overall  I recommend this game as it is a big improvement over the first Dishonored, the feeling I walked away with was that I got to enjoy a good experience and remember more of the side missions and explorative parts then I did the main storyline.  This game gets compared to Thief a lot however I don't think that's accurate as this game really focuses on assassinating targets (either lethally or non-lethally) and you play as a bold and almost heroic player, saving this person or seeking revenge on that person whereas Thief was more about stealing valueable items to pay rent, score a favor with a fence or to keep some faction off your back and most importantly trying to stay out of the spotlight. Garrett and Corvo are very different characters, both enjoyable in their own way but I wouldn't call the games these characters are from all that similar just because D2 has Stephen Russell and you can stealth.

As I write this review, I'm looking at all the E3 Awards this game won displayed on the side of it's store page. I myself highly anticipated this game; I own Dishonored 1 and both of the story DLC and had a blast playing through all of them.  However, as others have said, this game runs terribly on PC. My setup meets or exceeds the minimum requirements for this game and is near the recommended, yet -- even on the lowest settings -- the framerate seems to regularly hover below 20 fps and the mouse movement is rough and irregular. Once you reach the game's first open area, even turning reduces responsiveness and makes things run jaggedly. I even waited to try agin until after the recent 1.2 patch, and, while it does seem to have helped, it's not enough to make the game enjoyable to play.  This game is supposed to give you the feeling of stealthily and speedily moving across rooftops and pouncing on unaware guards, yet the performance issues make it feel like your character has Forrest Gump leg braces, instead. It's suprising to me that Bethesda -- once a publisher that dealt exclusively in PC games -- now has given only cursory review and effort to the PC ports in favor of console releases. Hopefully, over the next few weeks there will be more patches that bring the performance up to snuff for PCs meeting the requirements. Until then, this game is -- disappointingly -- Not Recommended.

If you're wondering whether or not you'll like Dishonored 2, you really just have to ask yourself if you liked Dishonored 1, because they're basically the same in terms of gameplay. If you were hoping the AI would be less erratic, or there would be more weapons for a lethal approach, or the guards would stop repeating themselves, none of that has changed in any significant amount. If you've never played the first game and don't know if you liked it or not then you should probably do that first, because the plot of 2 doesn't coddle players who think it's acceptable to start a series with the second entry, so if you haven't played the first game and its DLC storyline (which is especially important) you might not appreciate most of the characters as much. If you liked Dishonored 1 and want another game's worth of it, go right ahead, if you have the hardware to run it. The optimization isn't unplayable, but it seems to be very picky in which computers it will run on and which computers it will barely start on, and while my 970 and i5 3570k @4.4 GHz was able to run it at mostly max settings at around 60 fps, others with similar hardware have barely managed to reach that on low settings. I'm submitting my recommendation as positive because the game itself is great, but I hope Bethesda learns a lesson from the rest of the recommendations burning them at the stake to not try to release your game a day early if you aren't going to properly optimize it. The 'preorder and get the game a day early' scheme is the worst preorder idea I've ever seen and should've died with Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, and maybe now it really will.

Overall: Dishonoured 2 is a great stealth game but a terrible game if you want to go full on 'kill them all', which the game offers as an alternative to stealth (more on why this is terrible in the detail section below).  Length: It has taken me 26 hours to complete with Corvo, going stealth. I consider this value for money. I am currently going through it again as Emily doing a high chaos (full on 'kill them all!') approach.  Performance: I had some bad performance at the start but the beta patch eliminated almost every issue I had, FPS was up and everything seems okay apart from the occasional crash now and again but I am sure it will be sorted once the patch goes live.  Detail: I have thoroughly enjoyed Dishonoured 2, I love the stealthy gameplay and the powers, like the original, add a lot of options and ways to deal with the various situations you find yourself in. There is nothing quite like being surrounded and stopping time, killing everyone, then starting time again. Or using your powers to ghost through a level, never being seen. The stealth gameplay is the best I have played and the story had me interested from start to finish.  If you choose to not go the stealth route, I think you will be left unsatisfied. This is because the devs haven’t designed the game to be anything but a stealth game. So, this means your foes will never get the drop on you, they will always be on their predictable set paths and because the levels are designed to allow you to plan your approach, knowing what you are getting yourself into before you act, it is all too easy to kill everything that stands in your way even without using powers. Even if an alarm sounds, everything will be back to its predictable default if you go away for a bit.   The game never really puts your foes on edge, never prepares them for the threat you represent. There is a level where the target you must get to knows you are in the building but does nothing to hamper your progress. It all feels great if you are stealth but way too easy otherwise. Now throw in the powers and you are basically a god amongst mere mortals who couldn’t really care less and will happily go about their duties waiting to get ganked.  As a solution, it would have been good to have the level adapt to your approach going off your previous level behaviour. If it is clear you are on a rampage, like I was killing over 100 NPCs in one level, then surely the next level the guards should be unpredictable, more numerous and actively seeking you out? Rather than standing guard and talking about having whiskey and cigars tonight.  My advice is to go stealth on your first playthrough then try a full-on assault playthrough next but bear in mind it is so easy it gets boring, even if you choose not to use any powers, they simply wont see you coming.

Right, let’s get the negatives out of the way first:  - Issues at launch with bad fps, which made the game unplayable for the first week.   - Some issues with bugs like people being killed when I knocked them out and were linked via domino power.   - Adaptive resolution, I hate it! and what made it worse was the fact that I had to turn it off every time I loaded up the game.   BUT after the first patch sorted out the fps issues the game opened up into what Dishonored should be.   Positives:   + STORY: Obvious, but enjoyable with great returning characters and references to the first game.   + LEVEL DESIGN: Is back and is great with so many different ways of completing a level. (Clockwork mansion and Dust district mansion being standout levels).   + ABILATIES: So many different ways of using the powers you're given to neutralise targets and traverse the environment. (I love Domino, such a great idea).  + CHOICE: the choice to play as Corvo or Emily, the choice to build the powers how you want to match your own playstyle and the choice to go lethal or non-lethal.   + GRAPHICS: I can see some people not liking the graphics or the art style, but for me I think they suit the world perfectly.   All-in-all despite the initial bad launch with bad fps (which was sorted out for me in the first patch) Dishonored 2 has built on the very strong foundations that Dishonored put in place with a unique world, great level design and multiple paths of completion. When I think of what I wanted in a sequel from the first game I wanted one that: continued the story of the characters, visited new parts of the empire and retained the best gameplay elements.   If you loved the first game then you will find all you need in Dishonored 2, but be prepared that your machine has to be a bit beefy and accept that you will still get frame rate drops in certain areas.

This is one of the best designed games I've ever played. Yes, at launch it was unplayable for many people due to a bad PC port, but the patch which later came out fixed that, at least for me. It is entirely playable on my medium-low end laptop, alebeit only on medium graphics. Obviously bad launches are not to be encouraged, but considering the sheer unadulterated quality of this game, a little forgiveness is in order.   I'm going to keep this as brief as I can. The story is excellent, the world is atmospheric and well designed. The combat may be too simple and easy on lower difficulties but on harder ones you are forced to get creative and it becomes much more nuanced. Emily and Corvo both had different and equally fun sets of abilities, although one or two don't feel very useful, although that is partially matter of playstyle. It is a fairly short game, taking me only about 12 hours on my first playthrough, but it is exceedingly replayable. There might be three or four differant ways you could approach a given situation and it always feels fresh. As soon as I finihsed my high chaos playthrough as Emily I started a new one in which I plan to never be seen and never kill anyone, and after 5 hours it still feels fresh. I love that it lets you play the whole game without once killing an enemy, if you so chose, or lets you slaughter every single person in your path, and both feel equally rewarding.  But my single favorite aspect of the game is the level design. Every mission is large, explorable, and unique, usually with some twist or added mechanic. In one mission dust storms will occassionally blow through reducing visibility. In another, you make your way through a huge mechanical mansion which can transform as you pull levers. You can even slip out of the usual areas and make your way through the spaces between the shifting walls. In another, you have the ability to jump between the present and the past, solving puzzles by changing things in the past to affect the present. Every level is full of detail and atmosphere, and you are heavily encourage to explore them to track down runes which allow you to gain more abilities.   It's just all so well put together, every part working together to create a functional moving whole. Dishonored 1 is in my top 10 games of all time, and Dishonored 2 is right there next to it.   9/10. The single significant problem I have with it is that you are apparently expected to read more journals and books and listen to more audio logs than I did initially or the story doesn't quite make as much sense as you'd expect. [THIS REVIEW DOES CONTAIN SPOILERS]  After all of the negative reviews I've seen for this game, I'd never think that I would enjoy myself playing this more than the original dishonored, which is one of my most played stealth games on steam, but somehow I did.   I praise the decision in bringing back characters such as Delilah into the series, as I loved the Dishonored 1 DLCs Brigmore Witches and Knife Of Dunwall, both for attention to detail and character development, as you explore new areas from a completely new perspective. I did feel as if Delilah did deserve more time in development and this game was more than enough to satisfy this. The antagonist Delilah is fleshed out spectacularly throughout this story, along with some of my favourite twists to the dishonored franchise so far Delilah is Jessamine's sister who was cast out of the tower and left to poverty, with the false promise of the throne, and Meegan Foster being Billie Lurk.    The developers really upped their game in terms of their level creativity. A few that stand above include levels such as the Jindosh Mansion, a house filled with walking death traps, levers and puzzles, all while being disturbingly watched by the Grand Inventor as he detects your every move. It's challenging, complex, atmosphere, intense and in my eyes, one of the best designs for a Dishonored theme, Closely followed by maybe The Flooded District, which was one of my favourite settings through both of these games.   I feel as if life in the city was highly improved, with the idea of more civilian conversation, more areas where people could lay low, along with more dilemmas such as wreckages, abandoned homes etc. This was a large improvement from Dishonored 1 as while it did have some social dilemmas, it doesn't compare to 2. Along with being able to hear different opinions of situations going around them, for example, the two woman discussing the speech of the overseer during the Addermire mission.   While I did find the voice acting of The Outsider to be a strange change, I got used to it around the 7th Mission and was able to see his effort in filling the role was well done. However, in terms of the Protagonist, while I do find the addition of the character being able to give input on a situation, I feel like sometimes it was unnecessary, but I found it to be satisfying during story based events rather than minor things such as Object Activation, such as globes.   Also, small things such as glass panes and objects being more of an obstacle really helps with the realism of stealth and also makes you think before you decide to far reach straight into a window and think you're gonna be silent.   I was able to run this game with my 750ti and my Intel G3258 at low settings with the addition of max textures, for details and such, and was able to keep an fps of around 45-60, with the exception of getting close to gravehounds, which would affect it severely, but not for long. Overall I would give this game an 8/10, I would be more inclined to give a 9, if it were not for some glitches concerning certain power combos like domino and the affects you put with it, along with some glitches concerning detection when loading into a game, but sometimes with enemies detecting you almost instantly, even if they have not seen you once.

As a fan of the stealth genre, and with having taken some of my first stumbling steps many a year ago in the classic Thief franchise, Dishonored came almost out of nowhere and picked up the torch that seemed to have been dropped somewhere around the dawn of the new millennium. When the brand new Thief game turned out to be somewhat of a letdown (although I enjoyed it for what it offered), the hopes were high that Dishonored 2 would be able to keep carrying the high level of quality of both it's inspiration as well as it's own original game.  Not only does Dishonored 2 live up to my expectations, it even picks up some pieces lost in the near-death of the Thief franchise. None other than Stephen Russell, the original voice actor of Garret, the main character in the original Thief games, provides the smooth strokes of Corvo Attano this time around. On my first playthrough I simply had to keep playing as Corvo, partly because I grew so fond of him in the first game, and definitely because he now practically embodies everything I loved about Thief.  The gameplay is smooth and responsive throughout, with a plethora of ways to go about your business. As a stealth buff, and someone who loves games where you don't need to kill a single soul, I opted to do the Ghost and Clean Hands playthrough (never detected, no kills), and thus heavily invested in the stealth and traversal skills. The signature ability is definitely the Blink, allowing you to teleport a short distance, and it has seen a small upgrade taken from the DLC to the original game where you can now pause time while aiming your Blink, even in mid-air, allowing for some ridiculously cool moments.  Visually the game also stays strong, keeping with it's somewhat water-color inspired aesthetics from the original, albeit now in a souped-up id Tech 5 engine. Without a doubt, this is a gorgeous game. The level design is also superb, with wide open and often times very vertical maps filled to the brim with secrets and treasures for you to loot. I would definitely suggest you take your time going through it, both to soak in the visuals as well as to experience some of the hidden corners of the world.  But let's not avoid the elephant in the room: The performance. A lot of people have been having trouble running it, and while I can say that I was one of the lucky ones in that I had very little trouble playing the game, the state the game was released in was bad for many players. A number of patches have already been deployed, and I have seen a performance increase on my side as well, so the developers are definitely showing that they care about this fact.  Remember: A game with poor performance can usually be fixed, but a game that is just bad can most often not.  The bottom line is that Dishonored 2 is a fantastic game, bolstering great gameplay, superb world building and level design, and some absolutely spectacular visuals. To top it all of, it keeps carrying the Thief heritage with both pride and dignity, and I hope that this is not the last we see of this world.

Firstly, I would like to start off by saying that I was one of the seemingly few people that didn't have too many performance issues. That being said, I will be reviewing this game based on MY experiences only.  So first off, lets address the performance issues. For me, The performance was ok until I hit the main city, but after searching a bit, I found a fix for NVidia users to basically disable Nvidia's unoptimized turd known as Ansel. This boosted my performance massively by 30-40 more fps. For a while, the Mouse Input was absolutely horrible, however with the new beta patch, it has been pretty normal. Arkane should be putting out a performance patch in the coming weeks, as well as adding New Game+ and other features. That's pretty much it for the performance side, runs pretty well for me on the following specs:  i7 6700k 16 GB DDR4 RAM EVGA GTX 1080 FTW  (Using 1080p monitor, so I can't speak for performance on 1440p)  Alright, now for the actual game. The short answer is: this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece. The story, in my opinion, was fantastic. I feel that this was one of the few games that lived up to its predecesor. Couple the story with amazing level design, and you have yourself a fantastic game. Not only is the game good, it also looks like a painting. The art design team really out did themselves, and how Dishonored 2 wasn't nominated for GOTY in Art Design is beyond me. Similarly to the first game, Dishonored 2 has insane replayability value. Since you can play as both Emily and Corvo, you essentially get 2 playthroughs (thats not including low chaos, high chaos, no kill, etc playthroughs). If I recall, Polygon complained that Dishonored 2 had horrible voice acting. In my opinion, the voice acting was nowhere near horrible. Infact, I rather enjoyed the majority of it. It's nice that Corvo finally has a voice actor so you are no longer a silent protagonist, even if Corvo says some pretty obvious ♥♥♥♥ sometimes. Another thing that really stood out to me in Dishonred 2 was the combat. Somehow they managed to make Dishonored's combat even better. The gore is also 10x better than the first game. Skillwise, Corvo's skills are identical to the original game's skills, with some new upgrades. I cannot speak to Emily's skills as I have not done a playthrough with her yet.  Overall, I feel that Arkane did a really good job on this game, but was ♥♥♥♥ed over by Bethesda pushing for their release date. Quite a shame that the game had to suffer a terrible launch because of an overzealous publisher.

After 57 hours, 5 playthroughs and unlocking every achievement. I feel I have a good enough opinion on the game.  Dishonored 2 is a perfect sequel for my personal favourite game. It has built well on its gameplay with the introduction of two playable characters, each with their own power sets and the lore of Dishonored has been greatly expanded on with some questions left on the first game being answered. Yes there is performance issues but this can easily be fixed with some messing around in config files and video card settings. Or just wait for the upcoming patch.  Story: (SPOILERS FOR STORY INTRO)  The start of the story is weak, very weak in my opinion. We start off as Emily on her throne giving a speech on the 15th anniversary of Jessamines assassination from the first game. The first gift giver of the day is the Duke of Serkonos who was brought along the 'true' empress, the sister of Jessamine. The claimed rightful heir then announces she is the heir to the throne and she will be taking it and locking up Corvo and Emily and just like that most of the guards just turn their swords on you. No proof needed, a strange women with a distorted voice and questionable clothes comes in and says shes the true empress and everyone just believes her and pulls their sword on their empress of 15 years, it doesn't make any sense. The rest of the story makes up for this as you embark on another journey to get to the bottom of a plot against your empire, There are some good points in the story where we see revelations and parts where plot points come together and I felt myself drawn more into how this coup was formed. It creates a new feel for Dishonored, while not straying too far from what made the original great.  (END OF SPOILERS)  Gameplay:  Gameplay is just so close to perfection, the game's difficulties have actuallly been worked on to make a difference other than how much health you lose to hits. I played on very hard and being stealthy has never been so hard, enemies are so much more perceptive and I was as good as dead whenever I accidentally entered an enemies central vision. If i mistakenly entered an enemies peripharel vision I had very little time to react as the AI would hone in on my position as a result of the increased difficulty, it made me watch enemies routes and plan on how to avoid them, which made me more invested in my surroundings.  The powers have been worked on to bring in a more skill tree based format. Corvo keeps his powers from the first game although they have matured, giving him a choice of advancing his old powers for stealth or for full combat. Emily's powers seem more based on stealth, her Far Reach is the equivalent of blink but MUCH more useful and she has Domino, which lets her link enemies who will then share fates. This is one of the greatest abilities in the game and I found myself constantly using it in my playthrough to both save ammo and make combat less dangerous. Emily's Doppleganger and mesmerize are a must have for any stealth player as a way to distract enemies from youself.  The environment is also one of your biggest weapons. Glass bottles can know be thrown at enemie's heads for an instant knockout now, proving very useful for players low on sleep darts or saving them. Windows can also be used for the same thing but be careful, an enemy thrown into a window can either die or be knocked out, theres now way to ensure how they end up so be careful. You can also knockout people from the air or mid combat, which is something massively missing from the first game.  Overall:   Dishonored is a great singleplayer game, offering at the least 4 full different playthroughs for players to enjoy which proves very much worth its vaule. The story although starting slow and weak picks up towards the middle and really pulls out some good points to invest you in the world. World design is a massive step up from the original, with even more ways to go about a mission, more beautiful areas that give you an atmosphere of despair and hoplessness from the citizens. Players who love stealth can take the challenege of attempting the game without being scene which really feels like how the games meant to be played, its a great challenege. I cannot even put into words how great my expeirence of this game has been but you can understand your self if you purchase it, you will not regret it!  Tl:dr; Dishonored 2 is really good and you can play it a lot. It improved from the first but the start of the story is pretty slow.

I recently finished my first playthrough of the game on very hard going for low chaos with Corvo. I have to say that this game is phoenomanal. I was a huge fan of the first, and I love stealth games, so I was excited for this game. I was hoping that they wouldn't mess this one up, and thankfully they didn't. The game isn't perfect, but I definately recommend it.  The game's story is gripping and deep. It plays off of the first game and its DLC, so fans of the game will know what's going on. The start of the story is very abrupt, (even more so than the first game) but it tells you everything you need to know. This is the bad guy, she's really bad, find a way to take her down. There is a twist (sort of) that had me staring at the decision screen for a good ten minutes because I was genuinly torn on what to do. The ending is...meh.  Now the gameplay is really hit or miss. Unlike other stealth games, you can easily recover once you've been spotted, or not even sneak around at all. Sneaking around can be tedious and boring if you don't like stealth, and the combat is so simple that you shouldn't have any difficulties parrying and inta killing most enemies. The only real consequence for beeing spotted is....well being spotted. If you are going for a ghost run you will absolutely have to plan your way through a level...at first. Near the end of the game I felt like a god. You can get crazy overpowered if you collect all the bonecharms and runes. At about level 6 I had to stop myself from collecting any more because the game was getting too easy. It actually wasn't until the last level that I figured out the upgrade system had more than one page, and after that it was all over. The beaty of the game is that you can play it however you want. I simply stopped stopping time and seeing through walls, but if you use those all the way through the game will be a cakewalk. The only complaint that I personally have with the stealth system is how it tracks your detections. I like that it shows you at the end of the level how many times you were detected, but there was one time where I set off no alarms, didn't get into combat, and no enemy gaurds were alerted to my presence whatsoever, but somehow I was spotted thirteen times. I trust that I was spotted, I just wished I knew when. Unless I missed thirteen gaurds chasing after me, it's possible that you can be spotted without alerting anyone, and that's annoying.  All in all it was a good game, probably my favorite at this time. I'm excited to play through as Emily who has a whole new set of powers!  Oh yeah, performance issues. I almost forgot to put this in because they didn't bother me. Yeah I have to play on low until it gets optimized, but that doesn't really bother me. Oh well, I can live without seeing my reflection in the water.

If you liked Dishonored, you'll very likely enjoy Dishonored 2. It has the same excellent level design and world building as its predecessor, with improved AI and expanded abilities. Stealth and combat are equally compelling, though the silly morality system remains intact and still punishes you for killing people. There were some performance issues at launch but they've mostly been resolved as of this review. The only part of the game I found disappointing was the story and supporting cast. The story feels predictable and routine whereas the first game had a pretty major twist that turned everything on its head. The first game also had a large and diverse cast of supporting characters with whom you had meaningful interactions and were a large part of why the twist was so effective. By comparison, Dishonored 2's supporting cast is tiny and your interactions with them are pretty superficial.  If you haven't played Dishonored yet, you really should before buying Dishonored 2. The series is best described as Thief + Bioshock. If that sounds appealing to you, you'll be in for a treat. If not, the first game regularly goes on sale for $5 so it isn't exactly a big risk to try out. If you enjoy it, make sure to pick up the excellent DLC as well. Aside from being great, it also has a characters that play an important role in Dishonored 2.
