Right now Dishonored 1 is honestly a better looking game then Dishonored 2. Because of technical issues and the art direction unfortunately.  There is something seriously wrong with the post effects and antialiasing to the point where it has made me want to go play the first game instead - as the pixel crawling and terrible smudging/sampling artefacts spoil the experience so much. Either they have a graphics bug somewhere or this is the worst implementation of a modern deferred renderer in an AAA product to date (And they need to fly in the id-tech6 team to fix this pronto). It doesn't matter what settings are used.  Performance is still not very good or consistent at all. Although so far I haven't experienced what I have read from the worst reports. It is playable but not fluid. This is on the following spec with the settings (I tried them all) not really making any difference:  Dishonored 2, 1.3 patch 1920x1080 at various settings nVidia driver 376.19 GTX1080 8GB VRAM i7 3770K 32GB RAM Win7 64bit  If they don't really fix this then you are probably better waiting a few years until GPU's can brute force supersample this into something with decent image quality at a decent frame rate.  I understand what they were trying to do with the art direction by retaining elements of the originals impressionistic style but meshing it with more sophisticated realtime lighting - such as the faux subsurface scattering on characters and something that crosses between an oil painted look and more physically based reflections on metallic surfaces for example.  To be fair I don't think the artists did a bad job at all, and the art is very good, but overall it just doesn't quite reach the same visual heights and consistency of the first game. Trying to define and progress a new realtime impressionistic art style is a lofty goal, that they should be applauded for attempting.  The lighting doesn't look as good as in the first game. The quality of baked lighting is still hard to beat of course and especially so for a game like this.  Strangely the id-tech5 engine that was used in RAGE (One of the most beautiful games ever made still) has seemingly been butchered. The performance problems that engine used to have are long gone since the various graphics vendors fixed the unoptimised texture streaming paths in their graphics drivers a long time ago. As it was also a forward renderer it has fantastic MSAA quality so they probably would have had a much better result if they hadn't rewrote the rendering engine and designed the game around the id-tech5 engine instead (Although sure that may have caused issues for the clockwork mansion level).  Also as their game levels are smaller and due to tech advances over the years they could have had much higher texture resolution up close then RAGE had - fixing a common complaint. The impressionistic style done with unique texturing everywhere would have really been special for Dishonored2. But they ripped out megatextures and they actually downgraded the engine from OpenGL to DirectX11 bizarrely (OpenGL 4.3/4.5 is better then DirectX11). They probably would have had a better result sticking with UE3 rather than doing what they did.  There are lots of tell tale signs of sloppy or rushed deadline programming overall with things like the mouse pointer speed and response in the UI menus being awful. But I am sure they can at least fix these minor things.  As fantastic as Robin Lord Taylor can be on TV I found him much worse then the Outsiders' original voice actor - it felt like his first video game voice acting gig. The rest of the voice acting goes from great, to good, to bad, to perhaps badly directed. The opening of the story in the throne room could have been handled better but it at least got the game going quickly in a way that paralleled the first game. Really it is the combination of just enough world building and story to surround the fantastic gameplay in Dishonored that makes it work so well. So I have no real complaints there.  Gameplay wise the game is great however. Which makes it all the more disappointing that the visuals let the game down so much and ruin the experience. As shallow as that may sound it unfortunately is something that is at the very core of how Dishonored brings you into its' world.  Encountering the gigantic whale hung for slaughter in the first game left a lasting impression of awe with how amazing it all looked. When I came across the barnacle encrusted whales in Dishonored2 I thought wow they don't look quite as good but I 'could see where they were trying to go with it'.  I sincerely hope Arkane can improve the situation as they are obviously a very talented group that throughout their development history have taken some very brave design risks. This isn't a bad game at all, and is an improvement over the first in many areas. However the first Dishonored game was so consistently good in comparison it's going to be a tough one to beat even after many patches.
A fantastic follow-up, that improves on the original in every important respect.

When I heard Arkane were finally making a sequel to my beloved Dishonored I peed my pants a bit then I cried a bit because sequels to your most beloved games are often ♥♥♥♥♥, take Dragon Age II for example, a game I came to love but made me sick to my stomach after Origins. I was terrified that they would change it too much, try to be trendy and keep up with the kids, maybe include Minecraft inspired settlement building or an Angry Birds level or some other equally horrible commerical balls. However, I am ecstatic to say that Dishonored is still Dishonored, it still has the same lonely, gritty atmosphere, the same beautifully realised world, hidden secrets, tragic and incredibly drawn NPCs and is as rich in lore and intrigue as the original. The stealth and combat use the exact same mechanics too which means I was able to pick up my controller and hammer away at the buttons and die just as easily as I did the first time around. I will say that I am finding it much more challenging this time, but that is probably only because I played the original to death and need more practice.  I've chosen Emily for my first playthrough because it seems natural for the story to follow her events. She has some incredible new powers which I am still getting to grips with, particularly Doppelganger which projects a copy of her that the guards are supposed to chase leaving you to get away clean. My Doppelganger, however, runs towards me drawing the hostiles This is me being hopeless and drunk rather than the game I think...  The voices are wonderful, I was particularly worried about Corvo being voiced since he is supposed to be the classic silent protagonist but Stephen Russell (Garrett, Nick Valentine and Mercer Fray among othersl) is suble and somehow lovable in his role, as is Erica Lutrell as Emily. She manages to sound both like Chloe Moretz (young Emily) and like her mother, Jessamine Kaldwin voiced by April Stewart in the original.  Overall it is harder and creepier than before. Playing with headphones makes the guards' footsteps almost unbearably scary and there is this screaming, insane woman.. The tension has been ramped up along with enemies' lethality - be warned it seems to be much harder to escape when you thought you were just gonna smack that guard over the head with a whisky bottle...  A quick word about performance - yes I've been having issues with horrible lag too and no I don't play on a potato, or a toaster or microwave. My rig is top notch, although my best GPU died recently, my second best is still above and beyond recommended settings. Having said that its not, like, unplayable - it lags and stutters sometimes and combat is bloody difficult because of it, but I am still over the moon because it is Dishonored and they will make a patch and it fills my sad and lonely life with joy so peace out my gameplaying friends.  Dislikes: I'm not keen on the Outsider's new voice he sounds like he is on a combination of Helium and Caffeine, he needs to sound more mysterious and menacing, we're not having a chat in Starbucks, we're supposed to be in the goddam Void for chrissakes. I can't remember the others because I am drunk. Oh yeah, I die a lot but that's probably because I am drunk.   TL;DR Just buy the damn game already, unless your computer really is a potato.

The voice acting has suffered in some areas, and something about the game engine causes voice lines to trigger a bit too fast, making many conversations seem hasty and twisted as the characters seemingly try to cut one another off mid-sentence. The story, as well, seems to pick up a bit too hastily compared to the first game, and the whats and the why's, the motivations that drive many of the characters, are a bit too obscure.  All in all, while not perfect and not quite up to par with the first game, Dishonored 2 is a great game to put a few evenings into and it serves well both for those garnering for stealth-oriented gameplay or bloodthirsty and imaginative murder-fests. Great Game. Highly recommended. I had no issues with performance, at all: windows 10, i7, nvdia gfx900. If you prefer frenetic FPS games, this is not your one, get the awesome Doom (latest). If you've already played Dishonored 1 and you liked it then, you will be not disapointed, this is what you were waiting for. If you never played Dishonored but you like stealth games, as Splinter Cell or Thief or alike, you will be at home. Graphics are gorgeous and maps are large enough. Characters look so ugly and odd as in the first game, instead. The game can be played in any way you want: do you like to kill as a mad? you got it. Do you want to pass as a shadow? you got it. Do you want a mix of everything? you got it. Most of times, there is not a single path to do things so, re-playability is ensured. The more you play, the more you realize that you could did it other way. Total freedom to walk (or jump) across the scenarios, at floor level or high level. Recolection of runes and bones is just a way to visit the whole maps, which adds a lot of extra playing hours. Special mention to a couple of chapters, which are total mind-benders, very specially the one related to the Mechanic House (awesome !!!), but also the one with the parallel-time device (what an original and interesting idea !!!). I've only had some issues with the latest chapter (9) where the game crashed everytime that I had to fight against witches and spectral dogs so, I used the rats mood to avoid such crashes (but you can go the stealth way, anyway). At the beginning, I was surprised that Arkane/Bethesda used the ID-based Void engine, instead of the highly performant and reliable Unreal one but, everything made sense on the two awesome chapters mentioned above. ID engines are often giving issues to people and, I bet this is why this awesome game gets so bad reviews (and I can fully understand it, since I had same feeling with lot of ID-based games). Maybe, I was looking this time and, downloaded and played it after the second or third patch, which made my playing experience enjoyable. Please, if you are getting technical issues, be patient, wait until they are fixed but, don't miss this game, it's really a very good one and, your mind will blow up with those two mentioned chapters. Those two set this game appart the first one and any other game you've played.

First Playthrough with Emily on Hard difficulty. Low Chaos. Stealth Her Powers and Abilities are similar, but also quite different to her counterpart in the prequel. Including a movement spell (Far Reach) to either pull yourself towards a foe or a foe towards yourself. (Shadow Walk) is surprisingly effective for taking out single enemies, but the mana consumption per transformationmay seem to much for 'just a target'. Me on the other hand, i used this to avoid enemy detection in close proximity, as it makes you look like a shadow and thus hiding your presence. Unless you literally stand and touch an enemy. The last power, that I unlocked (and that Corvo doesn't have) is called 'Domino', which grants you the ability to link targets with each other (up to 4). The linked targets will share the same fate. Like if you knock one linked target out, so will be the remaining ones. This also applies to a more lethal approach. Highly recommended for situations with a high amount of enemy presence.   The game in general has improved a lot over the 4 years between the prequel and the release of the sequel. The PC Masterrace had some major issues with framerate drops for low-ende/budget and high-end machines alike. The precision weapon of choice, the mouse, also had input lags, which made the gameplay a lot more choppy. After around 2 weeks, Arkane Studios released a hotfix for the mentioned problems and it seems a lot more playable, even though I finished my first run before the patch.  Gameplay 9/10 (includes the almost infinite ways of overcoming an obstacle, many many upgrades. Apparently not a traditional Open-world game)  Sound 9/10 (eerie winds, whispers, waves crashing against the ship,...)  Graphics 10/10 (improved shadow and lighting, HD textures, juicy animations:both lethal and nonlethal takedowns)  Story 8/10 (Not gonna spoiler it)  Replay value 9/10 (You should at least play this game 4 times with different approaches: High chaos/ low chaos Emily + High chaos/ low chaos Corvo)  If you loved the prequel Dishonored 1. You'll love this sequel even more!  Looking forward to the DLCs.

tl;dr plot isn't amazing but the gameplay and amazing level design makes up for it  I spent 32 hours on my first playthrough of this game. I loved the original and was more than happy to purchase the sequal but I kept my hopes low in case the game didn't live up to it's name.  Luckily it did. Although there were some initial performance issues many have been drastically reduced or removed, granting me a 20+ fps boost if not more. It's still not perfect but performance is not a reason to give up on this title.  As far as gameplay, I've beaten the game once as Corvo playing full stealth, nonlethally, without powers, on the hardest difficulty. This run took me 32 hours and it revealed exactly how much thought went into the levels. The world is filled with back alleys, rooftops, hidden paths, and any number of other interesting scenarios to explore as well as some excellently-written lore pieces and notes. I don't normally like reading newspapers scattered in a game but Dishonored 2 made it worth it. Every mission was interesting and even my least favorite was still an amazing presentation of a level.  My one gripe is this, well, two things. As a small point there are a few lines of dialogue that seem unnatural or poorly read, but this is common in most games so I won't make a big deal of it. More importantly, because the game allows you to play without powers, there is almost always a way to reach an objective without them. This isn't a bad thing in and of itself but in playing again with powers some of the challenges now seem far too easy or not even like challenges at all. What previously took an hour now takes a minute with a few blinks or far-reaches. This might just be a result of my choosing to play without powers first but powers do certainly cheapen many of the games more challenging areas.  All in all I loved Dishonored 2, it might be my favorite game of the year. Consider it if you're a fan of the franchise or someone looking for a study in excellent level and mission design. Even though it's not perfect, Dishonored 2 is a game I'll be pouring much more time into and I'll be enjoying every minute.

Her new set of powers are refreshing enough to be interesting but still provide you with enough of the same to make your strategies from the first game valid. They've also definitely made it easier to differentiate between playing low or high chaos, which I quite enjoy since it feels more like a 'choice' rather than accidentally messing up an encounter and being screwed. Furthermore it feels like you have quite a bit more freedom in how to tackle every single mission, since there are many paths that lead towards the same goal, and it really challenged me to go explore.   All in all, what I loved about the original I love about Dishonored 2; the settings still feel almost magical and strange and make me want to explore, the characters all have their virtues and vices, the story is engaging and the stealth is actually fun instead of an impossibly frustrating task.

I don't usually write reviews, that's because I wish I had more time to come up with an in depth look into the game I'm playing to actually give it a worthy review. This game is great in my opinion, sure it has a few problems none of which are gamplay or graphic-wise (my biggest problem is with the change in the Outsider's voice but I can look past that and view the masterpiece in wake of that one flaw). The visuals are stunning to look at, the gameplay is hours of fun and the story is decent. The problem is in the game's optimizing apparently, and that's not something to look passed and say 'If it worked this would be a great game!' then give it a positive review based on what you hoped the gae would be. I personally have had no performance issues, so I guess I'm one of the lucky ones. So based on my experience of the game, the game is great! I'd recommend it for sure if there was a way of knowing for sure the game worked with your computer. Corvo's back! That's great (I haven't played as him yet), and his voice is perfect for him. The character didn't have a voice in the first game, and giving a beloved character who didn't speak in the first game a voice is always going to be risky, but I think by giving the role to the voice of Garrett from the 'Thief' series is a bonus, especially when you consider the thief games and their influence on the development of Dishonored. Our dear Emily has all grown up and you can play as her. Her abilities are interesting and differ greatly to Corvo's while still at times feeling reminicent as to make sure you're not unable to reach places as one character that you couldn't reach as the other. There's so much negativity in these reviews, and what I personally believe to be unnecessary negativity. I haven't had a single problem with the game not working, crashing or having low frame-rates and I know I'm one of the lucky ones who hasn't had issues. I feel like I need to dilute this negativity with my own positivity to some extent. So this is a place-holder for now in hopes that one day I'll actually be able to do this game justice but there needs to be more positive out there so I'm doing my part. If you're interested in purchasing the game... I'd have to say wait, but that doesn't mean I'm saying not to purchase. Definitely come back to this once it's been polished up a bit so you can live this experience the same way I've been fortunate enough to be able to.

What's the saying, the wings of a butterfly can cause a hurricane? Well in Dishonored 2, you get to see the hurricane.   Like the last game, your decisions influence the world around you, NPCs have different scripts due to your actions of high and low chaos. In low chaos you'll be able to watch two lovers sing while dancing on a top, in high, they killed each other. Perhaps you want to watch some idiot robbers try and trick you into helping them but when they fail to draw anyone, they laugh about it and go about their business but in another run, one of them kills the other for being a horrible actress.   Corvo and Emily also change due to your gameplay, becoming colder and deadlier or warmer and realizing the mistakes they made in the past.   The new powers are fun, the old powers are fun and there's more customization with the bone charms this time as you can make your own.  Finally a tip: Hit F to stop moving when using Emily's far reach. That power is fun but has lead to a many of my deaths.

After the recent 1.2 beta patch, I am changing my review. The game still doesn't reach 60 fps on my 960m, but it does play at stable 30fps in 900p on Medium preset, which is alright in terms of performance, especially since the game looks gorgeous even at these settings. However, if you have a high tier rig, you might still be very disappointed with your frames per second, even on lower settings and resolution. The combat is roughly as good as it was in the first game (which is quite a high standard to keep up), however there are more non-lethal options, which makes low chaos playthroughs a lot more dynamic than they were. The game is still very easy in terms of combat, maybe even easier, if you compare very hard to very hard (particularly due to new reflexes enhancement and slide-attack finisher), but in terms of stealth it is a lot more challenging, while at the same time providing more options, so overall ghost+clean hands playthrough is far less of a quickload simulator, which is a very positive change. The storyline feels rushed for a pretty simple reason: there are fewer targets for you to eliminate, and even those you do don't really feel as necessary as they are presented to you by the game. DH1 felt longer and less straightforward due to the betrayal twist, while DH2 has a more unified plot. Also, while maps have became significantly bigger, that is only due to their width and height, not their length, so a lot of the time you feel like you are prolonging the mission artificially. The characters are OK, I'd say they are better than what we had in DH1, but there are fewer of them, so that does't feel like a major side of the game. Voiceacting and most of the writing are absolutely amazing, however. Particularly the heart is very good, and as the game has a few 'peaceful' areas, you can get that RPG-esque feel of being in a living city, and not just in a big violent puzzle. The soundtrack is nice. In fact, I am listening to it right now, and I am even considering to load it to my player (if only there was a lossless version!), that's how good it really is. Too bad you don't hear much of it in the actual game. So even if you don't buy the game, at least listen to this masterpiece. What this game really exceeds at, are level design and atmosphere. And when I say level design, I mean both the visuals and gameplay part. Every building has some tactical options in it, and some theme that is either limiting or helping you. All the apartments and shops feel like actual appartments and shops. You rarely feel like some particular item is there just for the player, and not because it has it's reason to be there. Karnaca looks absolutely astonishing, and that's a rare case for a low-spec gamer like me. So, to sum this up, this game is certainly playable, despite all the performance issues and clearly the best game of 2016 to me and, probably, to anyone who treats games like art, not just blank entertainment.

From a quarter that is focused on mining, to a harbor, to an institute, to a huge, yet very closed off modernized castle. i dont feel as though i am wandering through the same streets everywhere i go. Firstly, make sure your graphics drivers are up to date kids.  Have played the first 1 hour or so including the tutorial. So far, absolutely none of the performance issues people are talking about, even though I seem to have similar specs to people supposedly suffering performance issues, in some cases less (GTX1070, i7-4970k non-overclocked, 16Gb DDR3 running off of a 250GB SSD) With V-Sync I get a straight 60, anywhere & everwhere, without V-Sync it hovers around 100 - 110.   HBAO+ does cause a performance (~100fps to ~80fps, not to be sneezed at) with no appreciable effect on graphics, so just leave it off.  There's lot of good graphics options here for us PC users, including FOV sliders.   For the game itself (and my ~1hr play time), it feels distinctly like Dishonored. I felt the plot starts a bit abruptly before really getting a chance to introduce the more mature characters, but even in the first 15 minutes you're giving a target to kill (or dispose of non-violently), have a beautiful mansion to explore and some audio tapes to listen to, to help set the mood (not to mention getting to choose between Corvo or Emily)  Definitely looking to get into.  TL;DR: Performance issues are hit and miss, some get it others (myself included) don't see them at all. Shaping up to be an excellent sequel.

Dishonored 2 is more Dishonored and I think that is a good thing. After the performance issues of the first week the game runs fine on my PC and I am enjoying it a lot.  There are two ways to play the game: As Corvo, the master assassin you took control of in the first game, or his daughter and now Empress of Dunwall Emily. During my first playthrough I am playing as Emily and have to say that the powers she has are a lot of fun. Shadow walk for example lets you crawl around a level more stealthily, and Domino lets you link two enemies in order to have their fatal fate shared. Of course the powers that were available in the first Dishonored do have a comeback here and there are all sorts of Bonecharms that give you extra perks, which can be very helpful to support your playstyle.  The other main character, like in the fist installment of this franchise, is the game world itself. The developers at Arcane Studios have put in a lot of effort to create a living and breathing world with interesting characters and locations that are filled with a ton of lovely details for you to find and fill your pockets with. I'm writing this review disregarding the performance issues, as most of you be well aware of it by the time you read this.  The game improves upon the original Dishonored in its level design and general elements of its stealth gameplay: guards are more perceptive, light/shadow contrasts are utilised more and height factors based on the level layout also affect where and how you should be sneaking. There's more tools for non-lethal playthroughs now; stun mines, drop-attacks and sting darts. It really feels like Arkane listened to feedback on the first game and delivered a solution. The levels in this game are phenominal, real wide open areas with tons of tiny details packed into them. Even the ones that aren't spectacles visually are still made interesting with lots of events, exploration opportunities and secrets to find. I'm really glad they kept this approach to level design over going open world like every other game feels they have to do now.  Along with solutions comes compromise; Dishonored 2 is a great game, and builds upon it's interesting lore with lots of audiographs, newspapers, letters and books to really make you invested in its world. Beyond all this, the writing falls short. The plot is a generic revenge plot outshadowed by Corvo's escapade 15 years earlier in the original game. Characters are dull - Erica Luttrell and Stephen Russell are fantastic voice actors that were wasted on monotone dialogue and commentary. The plot just doesn't have as much bite this time, you as a player don't feel urgency to pursue these assination targets as you did in the first game.  Nevertheless, even with the lesser points weighed in, Dishonored 2 is a great game with many options available for the player just as they were in the first. Worth playing, if not buying.

Game runs buttery smooth, haven't had any issues with performance and I'm running everything at highest settings (with the exception of TXAA). While not every setup will achieve this, I think it's important not to flood the page with bad reviews immediately. There were reports of TXAA being the culprit, and I doubt most people here have turned that off which means their 'reviews' are incomprehensive.  As for the gameplay itself, I was already a huge fan of the first DIshonored. I have not done a playthrough as Corvo yet so I can't compare how he plays in the first one to now, but Emily's playstyle is a refreshing change. It made me realize how much I relied on certain cheap tricks in the first game to get through, and they've all but removed or diminished all of those tricks to the point where I'm constantly having to think on my feet and come up with alternate strategies.  In short, I'm loving it. It plays much like the first one in that it's divided up in to missions, going so far as to even start them out with someone dropping you off at your mission start in a boat. The levels however are massive, easily twice the size of the previous games' levels, and they're absolutely steeped in lore, neat hidden nooks and crannys, and alternate routes. I'm up to mission 4 and so far, it definitely warrants at least a couple more replays. I'm already ready to revisit older levels to try and do better than I did previously.  While non-lethal seems to be much harder to pull off, they're more forgiving if you have to kill a couple of soldiers who spotted you. I've probably had to kill 20-30 soldiers, and I'm still operating in low chaos.  Overall the game runs fine on my system, yes they need to fix any compatibility issues with other systems (seems to be related more to AMD), but it's still an amazing game, and the port is well done in terms of options for customizability.  My specs: Windows 10 64-bit Intel i5-3570 ~3.4GHz NVIDI Geforce GTX 1070 24GB of RAM

I have been a very big fan of the Dishonored game since it came out. Allowing players to take multiple different styles of play to the maps and levels that they had made. So when Dishonored 2 was announced I was hyped, but after seeing the reviews I thought this game was gonna be just a crappy cash grab. And to be honest I'm disappointed in all these bad reviews.   I do have to acknowledge the fact that there are some big issues with framerate and optimization . In fact I had instances of extreme lag in parts of the game, and I'm some high mid-tier to top-tier parts in my setup. Thing is for us pc player, WE GOTTA GET OVER IT!!!! This game was obviously meant for console, and you just got get off your high horse and deal with it. Controls are sensitive? Well duh, play it with a controller if you hate it. Don't want too? Well then change the controls to how it fits you...  Patches will come, that's how pc gaming works. The game has just released for crying out loud. So let time pass a bit before you bombard it with bad reviews. They will fix it. They always try.  Now onto the actual review, game is a good game. I love it. Definitly lives up to the first game. Maps are big. Your actions control the ending. Different ways of playing, all just like the original. Controls are the same, which I will say sort of sucks but keybinding to the rescue! Basically a bigger, even better looking version of the original game, which I love.   Now what did they update or change? Well to begin with, abilities. New set for Emily and same set for Corvo. Emily's set of abilites are amazing, very unique abilities allowing for very interesting was of taking down foes, but still allowing players to play any way they choose. Corvo's is the same so nothing really to say. Now, the upgrading of the abilities is was really stands out, you can upgrade your abilities based off what you want. Just know. stopping time is great for planning tactics. So get it for Corvo's Blink (Just like Daud's Blink, YEAH BABY!!!) and Emily's Far Reach. Everything else, do as you play.   Maps have dramatically increased in size overall. Which you'd think would make it easier to stealth, right? Nope it's harder because of how open it is, and that is pretty cool (Also enemies are more perseptive, even at normal difficulty, so watch out for them if you're playing stealthily). Added bone charm and rune crafting, awesome. Great way to amp up play styles. Also made keeping specific Chaos levels easier. which is nice when going for a low chaos run.   Overall it's a good game. If you're not a pretentious snob, who expects godlike perfection right out of the box for a pc port. Then I'd recommend it, for the snobs. BTFO UNTIL IT MEETS YOUR STANDARDS. Then play it.

UPDATE: Nominated this game for the 'Most Deserving of a Second Chance' award  I'm going to do my part in giving this game a thumbs up since it breaks my heart that two of my favorite recent stealth games have been given mixed reviews on Steam.   Dishonored 2 is a FANTASTIC game. We all know the problems with the performance and I certainly don't approve of how they handled the game's PC launch; however, now that I've installed the beta patch and begun playing it runs buttery smooth on my GTX 970, and the gameplay is absolutely sublime.   The biggest drawback of the game in my opinion is the story, honestly. Perhaps I just haven't gotten far enough in it yet, but there doesn't seem to be as much of a sense of revenge building up in the player throughout the game like in Dishonored 1. In the first game, you initially want revenge on Daud and the Lord Regent, but then you're betrayed and your lust for revenge gets even stronger. In this game, other than wanting revenge on Delilah, there isn't much that drives me.  However, what DOES drive me is the gameplay and level design. Both are expertly crafted, with power usage responsive and allowing for even more creative ways to deal with your opponents than was possible in Dishonored 1, which was already an enormous number. Add that on top of Emily's powers, and this game has a lot of replayability.   If it didn't have the initial performance issues, it would be a 10/10 from me. But alas, I'll have to knock one point off.  9/10 - DO BUY if you're into stealth games or anything like them

The level design - ie the gameplay - is 10/10 here as with Dishonored 1. The mansion where you can switch back and forth between the past and the present is one of the best levels I've played in my life. There are multiple solutions to all problems and lots of hidden missions in the books and overheard conversations. The game is brutally hard until you get some of the magic powers so don't judge by the first level. Fall damage is stupidly high considering the verticality of the maps and leads to save-scum frustration. Some level design decisions are a bit killjoy-ish, often funelling you into the front door where D1 would have give you 5 alterative and smarter ways (some that you'd discover on your 5th replay).  Art direction is fantastic though the graphics themselves aren't *that* huge an improvement over D1, and everyone knows about the appalling optimisation issues at the moment (1080+6700=40FPS at times). The biggest negative with D2 for me is the story which is much less focused than D1, so it's just kill target A to get name of target B, rinse and repeat until the short closing cinematics. The opening premise is stretched and does not help to get you to suspend disbelief. I miss the exposition of a 'Samuel the boatman' type figure or the 'party camp' feel of the Hound Pits base (D2's ship is a pale shadow of this). These all give you a purpose beyond simply 'beating a brilliantly designed level'.

DisHonored.  A brilliant, gorgeous little game from Arkane and Bethesda. Loved everything about it and hoped for a sequel.   And now, we have one. DisHonored II is everything great about the first and then some.  Set 15 years after the first game it continues to story of Corvo and Emily, this time giving you the choice of who you play as. I, of course, picked Corvo. He simply seems like the correct choice.  I really like that the story brings in characters and elements from the first game's DLC chapters and makes them main players now.  Add in the game looks fantastic. It still maintains the beautiful oil painting look of the first game, only far more detailed. Better lighting, animations... it's a gorgeous game.   And the gameplay feels far more balanced. Opting for a non-lethal playthrough feels far more balanced then it did in the first game, now that you have more options for taking out enemies in a non-lethal manor.  It's hard to really break down, but this is everything fans wanted from a DisHonored sequel. And I can't wait to play more.   But now... issues.   As of release, the PC version is not what most wanted. There are performance issues and mouse aim/movement issues. And these are frustrating, annoying and can even be irritating.  As of right now, it doesn't seem to matter what settings I use the game runs almost exactly the same. When it's at 60fps it's fantastic. But, there's something off in the game's frame pacing. With v-sync off, it doesn't matter what the FPS is, 45 or 105... it doesn't feel smooth.  Yet, with v-sync on, so long as it's at 60 it feels great. But, the second it drops to 55fps it feels jittery.   Now, Arkane have already commented and stated a fix is coming in the 'coming days' which will address performance issues and mouse movement problems.  But, even with these issues I can still easily recommend this game to those mature enough to see the brilliant game despite the few rough edges.  EDIT: With the release of the latest Beta patch the game has become far more enjoyable. Easier to obtain a solid 60fps, and with far less frame rate drops and hiccups. Arkane are in the right path to making this game a classic in every way.

TL;DR  ------------------------ CONS:  -Mouse acceleration/smoothing ~ easily FIXED by enabling V-Sync, -Bounce off the surface when using Far Reach while falling ~ (Emily), -Performance drop when alt-tabbing/minimizing the game.  PROS: -EVERYTHING ELSE!!! ------------------------    I bought Dishonored 2 ignoring all these negative reviews because most were about bad optimization and whatnot.   To set the record straight -- the game IS NOT poorly optimized, you're just too big of a mongloid to adjust the settings properly or simply think you can run the game maxed out with a 2010 computer/components.   The only problem is the mouse smoothing/acceleration, which is EASILY FIXED by enabling V-Sync. Yes, you will limit your FPS but who cares? Those 60 locked frames are just perfect for this game because it's not a game about admiring the graphics or the scenery, but sneaking around and carefully getting past (or getting rid of) the enemies and of course it's gameplay aka combat system.  That being said, it's the only CON in my eyes (and also a HUGE drop in performance when alt-tabbing/minimizing out of the game + maybe falling and then using Far Reach which weridly bounces you randomly and you don't always end up where you wanted to).   Putting that aside, I run the game on preset (Very High mostly everything (shadows and water quality being on High and lens flare + all that disabled) and I get 100 FPS minimum if I disable V-Sync. I have a GTX 1070 G1, 16GB RAM, i7 3770 and W7.  The story is fine, the visuals and gameplay are smooth and fun and it's a big upgrade from the 1st. Considering you can choose from 2 characters and with that the play style, it's damn awesome. A lot of replay value and the amount of different approaches you can take to complete your mission just makes you coming back for more. Of course the achievements are also something you shouldn't ignore and just add up to all the fun you can have from the game.    I definitely recommend the game, however, keep in mind it's a demanding so I wouldn't really recommend buying it if you don't have the newest graphics card or a somewhat powerful PC (even with the older GPU). That aside, I personally don't think the game is worth it's original price and I never would have paid it. In my opinion, it's worth around 40€ but not 60€.

*edit* - So I'd be curious to know: is this getting down voted because it's a poorly written review, or because I recommend the game? If it's the former I'd love to get some feedback to improve future reviews. Thanks!  bought on GMG. So I think this will show up as a key activation review?   I'm loving this game. Full stop - the visual design of the world is exceptional, and the gameplay is thoroughly engaging. Each mission introduces a new structural problem - you never feel like you're playing the same mission over and over. Each one is fresh, and recalls the best of Thief 2.   The high level story is weak, which I think is a consequence of having interchangeable protagonists. I don't know how you tell a meaningful story where the lead character is replaceable. BUT the NPC character stories are exceptional. Mission 7's hero NPC is a particular stand out - I was really moved by the nuance presented in that character's backstory.   Definitely had stability problems, but solved them by lowering presets. I've got a 970, 16gb ram, a beefy i7 and have to keep video settings at 'medium.' The game looks amazing even at that level, and I maintain 60fps all through, but it's been a little frustrating to not be able to see the game in its full glory. There's no new game plus or mission selecting, but I've read the devs have considered patching it.  But as of right now, the game runs like crap. On high settings (the third highest), I get about 25-60 FPS. The dips and drops can be very jarring to experience and it's a simple indication that the developers got incredibly lazy with their PC port. Under that simple problem alone, you should NOT buy this game.  Wait for a bit. If they fix it, then they deserve your money. If they don't, their loss.

I had heard a lot about what a let down this game was and I wasn't going to get it, but I'm actually pretty glad that I did! Don't get me wrong, the performance is definitely not optimized, but it's far from game breaking. There are two things you can do to fix performance issues:  1. It's very important that, until they patch it, you set your advanced video settings to custom and completely disable Anti-Aliasing. Doing this more than doubled my frame rates. I play with everything else on Ultra, besides Viewing Distance which is set on High.  2. Download (for free) 'Process Lasso.' A part of the problem people are experiencing is due to the game being given low priority in task manager. Process Lasso is a real time optimization utility. You will want to set Dishonored 2 to high priorirty.  I have come across some inconsequential moments where the frame rates have dropped as low as the 30, but this has only happened three times so far and never in the places that matter. The frame rate drops I've experienced have all been outside of combat, not in big areas, but rather in small spaces or indoors where my character is often alone. They also don't last long. Split seconds.  Other than those few hiccups, I've been able to maintain steady 60fps at 1080p HD (on Ultra and I don't even have top of the line hardware). The gameplay itself is great and the combat mechanics, as always, are some of the best. I like the addition of a new character and actually really enjoy her move set. I've been lucky and had no PC issues. Nonetheless, I don't find myself as enthralled this time around. It offers more of the first game, but very little in the way of innovation.  The changes to the chaos system still leave me feeling shackled to a non lethal/low chaos playthrough, as I'd like to get a good ending.   Emily's powers either feel cheap or underwhemling. She has little that is interesting when compared with Corvo's abilities. Her teleport/pull move is frustrating, especially when compared to how easily Corve can teleport around.  The levels aren't super exciting. Kirin Jindosh's mansion at first seems like it will be extremely complex, but even after getting all the collectables and the non lethal finish, I felt like I had missed most of it.   What will or won't alert people feels confusing and inconsistent. In one scenario, pulling an item to me alerts all the guards, in another similar scenario, no one notices. Also if a guard sits down on leans on something, he is immediately protected from your stealth attacks.  As a fan of the first game, it was nice to return to the universe, and I still feel like these are better Thief games then modern Thief. I'm glad I got more Dishonored, but I wish I also got a bit more.

Update -1: On the topic of optimization, I would reiterate what I say below. I have not had many issues on a technical side. However, I cannot speak for everyone's experience. IF you're below the recommended, I would suggest waiting a few weeks to pick it up until they iron the issues out. Hell, maybe wait even if you ARE above the recommended.  Update -2 11/14/16 - I've been very patient. I paused my playthrough waiting for a stablization patch to fix the issues reported by gaming outlets. It's been nothing but radio silence from Arkane since the patch was announced. Such simple things such as graphical pre-sets not taking effect is not cool on the Devs part, and I'll be switching this review to Not Recommended until it's resolved.  Update -3 11/24/16 - I've waited and I've gone back into the game. On the small test I took (strolling around the Dust district) I'm now pleasently surprised that my 980 is running the game with all settings maxed out @ 60 FPS at 1920x1080. Switching the review back to recommended. Still gotta give some ♥♥♥♥ to Arkane for taking as long as they did, and not having this stuff fixed before hand.  == Original review w/ Updates below ==  People seem to think that because it won't run on their Grand mama's toaster that the game is poorly optimized. i7 6700K, Gigabyte Windforce GTX 980 3X OC, most settings maxed out (including AA) with HBAO+ off, game has yet to dip below 70 FPS at any time. Take 'LEL BAD OPTIMIZASHUN' complaints with a grain of salt, probably the same crowd who ruined Deus Ex: Mankind Divided's reviews. Doubly so considering the release date hasn't actually hit yet, and that the Dev's can only account for so much without testing the game in the wild. I will update this as I get further into the game.  Update 1: So far, after playing for 9-10 hours as I'm writing this, my only complaint(s) are these. First is that it doesn't seem to like my particular dual monitor set up (I have my main in my GPU and my second in my Mobo because it's an an old 1400x1050 VGA monitor) but that was fixed after a restart. The second is that they didn't do a lot to the powers. They added some new ones yes, but none that I feel would benefit me except for one, otherwise I've been getting away clean with my core powers from Dishonored 1 (Blink, Dark Vision and Agility + the new one, Domino)  On the technical side, I've encountered no bugs except the dual montior issue (which might be me) and that I fell through an elevator and took a small amount of damage in the Addelmire level. The sound of the game is just awesome, it feels different but the same (which works for a game set 15 years after the first) The graphics aren't the most spectacular I've ever seen, but thats because I did end up having to downgrade some stuff, even after getting out of the prologue. I'm also still playing on a 1920x1080 monitor, though, too. So far I'll say what I said when DXMD came out. If you're on the fence because of other people crying 'bad optimization' or 'poor port' then wait about a week or two, let Arkane do their jobs and fix what they could not account for.  Update 2: So far, so frustrating. Maybe it's an issue with just Emily, but this auto-target for powers is some of the most frustrating ♥♥♥♥ ever. I can't count the number of times so far that I've had a clear get away from a hairy situation get screwed over because instead of blinking to the ledge that I'm aiming at, the autoaim is making me aim at the ground below me, causing me to go face first back into what I'm trying to get AWAY from. At one point, I wasn't even in a hurry, just trying to blink up to a ledge that was right in front/above me. I aimed up at the ledge (just out of Jumping distance, even with Agility) and the game kept aiming my Far Reach at the ground, and trying to jump then cast did less than nothing to help. Whats worse is that there doesn't seem to be a way to toggle this crap at the very least.  I've encountered another bug since my last update.    I was working towards Kirin Jindosh's mansion to rescue Sokolov    and had successfully knocked out a majority of people in my way, except for this one guy with his back to me at a check point. I waited until his friend passed by hidind behind the wall, but was somehow seen through the metal wall, anyway. Okay, then. I managed to reorient myself and avoid detection at that instance, only for him to walk to my side, then clip through the door onto my head and start attacking me.

New patch seems to have fixed the majority of performance problems I was having. The game is great, a worthy sequel to the first one. If you liked Dishonored, chances are you're gonna enjoy Dishonored 2 a great deal.   Gameplay-wise pretty much everything was improved upon from the first game as far as I can tell. It feels more sleek, combat is even more brutal and impactful, and non-lethal playstyles are more versatile now. Absolutely no complaints on this front, the game feels great to play.  What I will say though is that I didn't quite get the amazing atmosphere from the first game (this is mostly due to the game's setting), and the story and characters (with some exceptions) didn't feel as strong in Dishonored 2 compared to its predecessor. This is just personal opinion, of course, but for me Dishonored (one of my absolute favorite games of all time) will remain the more beloved game of the franchise.  All in all, wheter you are a veteran of the first game like I am, or a newcomer to the series, I can only recommend this title.
